title: Pop quiz: does '5' equal 5 in code?
description: Pop quiz: does '5' equal 5 in code? Ania explains here.
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org
transcript:
Pop quiz. Does five equal five? With
double equals, yes. JavaScript converts
the string to a number. But triple
equals, nope. It checks type and value.
Always use triple equals to avoid
surprises.

title: Do something toward learning programming every day - even if it's just 10 minutes
description: When you're learning to code, try to do something every day - even if it's just 10 minutes. A little is better than nothing, and it's also manageable so you don't burn out.
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org
transcript:
like what would you recommend they do if
they want to be able to get a job as
quickly as possible as a software
engineer?
>> Yeah. So do something every day even if
it's 10 minutes and stick with it. I did
in my journey to learn end up taking
some breaks for various reasons. You
know my learning took a course of over 3
years. It can be done in less than a
year if you stick with it. I really I
fully believe that that you can do it in
less than a year if you you know spend
time every day. If it's listening to 10
minutes of a podcast on your way to
work, if it's doing some leak code real
quick or doing the next module at free
code camp, just get in and do something
at least every day so that your mind
continues to grow. And those little
actions, they add up at the end of the
year. And I think that's the biggest
thing is to try to keep with it. Don't
overwhelm yourself and try to cram in 5
hours a day every day. You'll burn out.
Like, but try to do something every day
that keeps your mind active and keeps
your brain in the learning mode to be
able to expand your knowledge and
skills.

title: Learn CSS Flexbox in 2 Hours ‚Äì Tutorial for Beginners
description:
CSS Flexbox will help you create flexible and efficient one-dimensional layouts for your HTML websites. Learn all about CSS Flexbox in this comprehensive video course from @codewithindra7. Flexbox transforms an ordinary container into a flexible box where you can precisely control its children, known as flex items. 

‚ù§Ô∏è Try interactive CSS courses we love, right in your browser: https://scrimba.com/freeCodeCamp-CSS (Made possible by a grant from our friends at Scrimba)

00:00 Introduction to CSS Flexbox
00:07 What is CSS Flexbox (Detailed Definition)
01:48 Benefits of Using CSS Flexbox
02:28 Align and Center Elements Easily
02:36 Develop Responsive Layouts (Fewer Media Queries)
02:41 Reorder Elements without Changing HTML
02:46 Create Same-Height Columns
03:34 Real-World Examples of Flexbox Use
03:55 GitHub Navigation Bar Example
04:46 Anatomy of a Flex Container and Flex Items
05:41 DataDog Website Layout Example
06:57 Recommended Resources for CSS Flexbox
07:07 FreeCodeCamp CSS Flexbox Handbook
07:41 Mozilla Developer Network (MDN)
08:11 Local Development Environment Setup
08:17 Code Editor VS Code
08:41 Browser Google Chrome
08:58 Initial Project Setup in VS Code
09:42 Creating index.html and styles.css
10:48 VS Code Live Server Extension
13:29 Flexbox Terminology Container and Items
13:47 Setting display flex or display inline-flex
14:38 Setting up Starter HTML/CSS for Examples
17:01 Adding Unique Colors to Flex Items
19:38 Applying display flex
21:50 Main Axis and Cross Axis Explained
25:26 display flex vs display inline-flex
27:31 flex-direction Property
29:21 flex-direction row (Default)
29:45 flex-direction row-reverse
30:54 flex-direction column
31:40 flex-direction column-reverse
34:01 flex-wrap Property
35:42 flex-wrap nowrap (Default)
36:19 flex-wrap wrap
40:40 flex-wrap wrap-reverse
43:24 flex-flow Shorthand Property
48:57 justify-content Property (Main Axis Alignment)
49:50 justify-content flex-start (Default)
50:15 justify-content flex-end
51:40 justify-content space-between
52:26 justify-content space-around
53:08 justify-content space-evenly
56:56 justify-content center
01:01:46 align-items Property (Cross Axis Alignment)
01:03:15 align-items stretch (Default)
01:03:54 align-items flex-start
01:04:14 align-items flex-end
01:05:27 align-items center
01:05:46 Centering an Element Horizontally and Vertically
01:08:26 align-content Property (Multi-line Cross Axis Alignment)
01:10:15 align-content flex-start
01:10:33 align-content flex-end
01:10:47 align-content center
01:11:05 align-content space-between
01:11:26 align-content space-around
01:11:38 align-content space-evenly
01:13:50 place-content Shorthand (Align + Justify Content)
01:18:24 align-self Property (Individual Item Cross Axis Alignment)
01:24:42 order Property (Reordering Flex Items)
01:32:26 flex-grow Property
01:37:06 flex-shrink Property
01:42:08 flex-basis Property (Initial Main Size)
01:47:07 flex Shorthand Property (Grow, Shrink, Basis)
01:53:59 flex initial (Cannot Grow, Can Shrink)
01:56:17 flex auto (Can Grow & Shrink)
01:57:14 flex none (Inflexible, Neither Grows Nor Shrinks)
01:58:36 gap Property (Row Gap and Column Gap)
02:04:00 PRACTICE PROJECT 1 Center Element H/V
02:07:32 PRACTICE PROJECT 2 Building a Simple Navigation Bar
02:14:44 Conclusion

title: When NOT to use AI in your hackathon project with MLH winners Cindy Cui and Alison Co [Podcast #198]
description:
Today Quincy Larson interviews Alison Co and Cindy Cui, two university students who won the NW Hacks hackathon with their tool that helps people who are losing their vision learn to read Braille. He met them when GitHub invited them to their big San Francisco conference, GitHub Universe to present their project.

Chapters:
- 0:00:00 Introduction & Community News
- 0:00:19 New Courses and Tutorials
- 0:03:59 Song of the Week & Shirt Info
- 0:06:54 The Braillearn Hackathon Project
- 0:12:08 The 24-Hour Building Process (Hardware & Software)
- 0:25:34 After the Win: GitHub Universe
- 0:33:10 Backgrounds, Grit, and Internship Advice
- 0:45:15 AI in the Workforce and Education
- 0:57:48 Future Plans and Final Advice

Support for this podcast is provided by a grant from AlgoMonster. AlgoMonster is a platform that teaches data structure and algorithm patterns in a structured sequence, so you can approach technical interview questions more systematically. Their curriculum covers patterns like sliding window, two-pointers, graph search, and dynamic programming, helping you learn each pattern once and apply it to solve many problems. Start a structured interview prep routine at https://algo.monster/freecodecamp

Support also comes from the 10,338 kind folks who donate to our charity each month. Join them and support our mission at https://donate.freecodecamp.org

Get a freeCodeCamp tshirt for $20 with free shipping anywhere in the US: https://shop.freecodecamp.org

Alison Co is a software engineer who's graduating Fall 2026. She's among the prestigious Major League Hacking Top 50 hackers. She's interned at Hubspot and will soon start interning at Rippling. 

Cindy Cui is a software engineer who's graduating Spring 2026. She's interning as a backend developer at Shopify. She also teaches violin and holds the prestigious Level 10 Violin certification from the Royal Conservatory of Music.

We talk about:
- Tips for securing good internships
- How they use AI as university students and as devs, and its limits
- How they built their winning hackathon project to help people losing their vision learn to read braille

Links from our discussion:
- A 45-second demo of Braillelearn I recorded in the shuttle with Alison and Cindy at GitHub Universe: https://youtube.com/shorts/a7B-JvPgTQs
- The Braillearn website: https://braillearn.vercel.app/
- Braillearn on GitHub: https://github.com/co-alison/nwhacks-2025
- Alison on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/alison-co-3634721b7/
- Cindy on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/cindy-cui/

Community news section:

1. freeCodeCamp just published a Discrete Mathematics for beginners course. It'll teach you tons of math concepts that are key to modern Machine Learning. You'll learn some Number Theory and Combinatorics, then use Python to explore the Pigeonhole Principle, the Stars and Bars Principle, Stirling Numbers, the Chinese Remainder Theorem, and more. (9 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/learn-discrete-mathematics/

2. We also published this JavaScript course on the open source n8n agentic workflow automation tool. freeCodeCamp instructor Gavin Lon will teach you core concepts like working with loops, trigger nodes, webhooks, and more. You can code along at home and build 4 real-world projects. (3 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/build-complex-workflows-with-n8n-and-master-ai-integration/

3. Learn the popular Vue.js front end JavaScript framework. You'll learn Vue's core building blocks like components, reactivity, template syntax, dynamic data binding, and asset handling. By the end of the course, you'll have a simple Vue app that you can show to your friends. Also note that I recently interviewed Evan You, the creator of Vue, on the freeCodeCamp podcast. (2 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/learn-vuejs-javascript-framework-course/

4. Learn how to run an open source LLM locally on your own hardware using Ollama. This is a great way to unlock the power of LLMs without the privacy and security tradeoffs of using public LLM websites and APIs. This freeCodeCamp guide will walk you through the setup process and give you a feel for the options at your disposal. (10 minute read): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/how-to-run-an-open-source-llm-on-your-personal-computer-run-ollama-locally/

5. Learn about the eccentric designer Luigi Colani and his biomorphic designs that imitate nature. This video essay dives into the German designer's life history and his body of work. Why were his designs so broadly disliked by the design establishment? In what ways was he ahead of his time? How did he influence the development of cameras, or design a gas-powered car that got 130 miles to the gallon? 30 minute watch: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SVo7H3EheMY

6. Today's song of the week is Leon Ware's 1982 classic "Why I Came to California".  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k1gwc9HJARU

title: Do you know who the first computer programmer was?
description: Do you know who the first computer programmer was? She was a woman named Ada Lovelace - back in the 1840s! This goes to show that programming has always been for anyone who wants to learn.
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org
transcript:
The world's first programmer wasn't a
man. It was Ada Love Lace back in the
1800s. She wrote an algorithm for a
machine that didn't even exist yet. Talk
about coding in hard mode.

title: Create a Cute Room Portfolio with Blender, Three.js, JavaScript ‚Äì Beginner Course
description:
Learn how to use Three.js and Blender to design a stunning and interactive 3D portfolio!

Course from @andrewwoan 

Intro to Creative Web Dev: https://youtu.be/yhtdkuw9mbM

*IMPORTANT*
Make sure to go into 1) edit in the upper left corner 2) preferences 3) system
4) and switch to "CUDA" OR "Optix" and enable your GPU if you've got one! If you're on Mac
your settings will probably be different: Select "Metal" instead of "CUDA" if you've got
something like an M1 chip. For either device switch to GPU compute as it'll be faster, unless
somehow you have a device where your CPU is better.

*IMPORTANT*
When baking you typically want to go for .01, I think I did .003 which is a bit
too small. If you have UVPackmaster3 you can set a pixel margin, if you're at 4k it should be
32px, at 2k it should be 16px, 1k at 8px etc. Obviously it depends on your use case, but
those are recommended ranges!!

Correction:
46:00 Sorry, accidental cut here, use the loop tools addon we installed and with those faces
selected 1.) right click 2.) loop tools 3.) circle!

Live site: http://sooahs-room-folio.com/

Code, Blender file, fixes, updates, credits: https://github.com/andrewwoan/sooahkimsfolio
If you are using Blender 4.5+ you can switch from OpenGL to Vulkan for a possible speed
increase.

Questions, comments, concerns? Contact andrewwoan@gmail.com and on Discord discord.gg/6F7dfuD5GT

title: JavaScript Clean Code Course ‚Äì Fix Code Smells & Refactor
description:
Learn how to transform messy, hard-to-maintain JavaScript code into clean, readable, and professional-quality code that scales. In this course from @tapasadhikary you‚Äôll understand what Code Smell is, why it matters, and how to refactor step-by-step using proven clean code principles, real examples, and modern tooling like ESLint + Prettier.

- Prettier: https://prettier.io/docs/
- ESLint: https://eslint.org/docs/latest/use/getting-started
- Clean Code Book: Search Clean Code Book by Robert C Martin
- Martin Fowler Blog: https://martinfowler.com/bliki/CodeSmell.html
- Clean Code Cheatsheet: https://www.tapascript.io/books/js-clean-code

title: Did you know that you can buy a domain name that's an emoji?
description: Did you know that you can buy a domain name that's just an emoji? Yep! You could have üçï .com, for example. Know anyone who needs a major rebrand...?
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org
transcript:
You can actually buy websites made
entirely of emojis like cat.ws or
pizza.tk.
Share this with someone who needs a
rebrand.

title: Intro to Backend Web Development ‚Äì Node.js & Express Tutorial for Beginners
description:
This introductory guide teaches you how to construct a basic backend for a website using popular technologies like Node.js, Express.js, and the MongoDB NoSQL database. The tutorial covers the core components of backend development, walking you through the initial server setup, database connection, and code structure using a model, route, and controller pattern. You will learn to build practical APIs for user authentication, including password hashing, as well as full CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations to manage data. Finally, the video demonstrates how to utilize Postman to test your server's requests and ensure your APIs are functioning correctly.

This course was developed by Shivani. She is part of Hack Club. Hack Club is a global non-profit organization that creates a community for high school students interested in coding and making things with technology.

Hack Club is free and any teenager can join. Check out their site to get stickers and learn more: https://hackclub.com/

‚≠êÔ∏è Contents ‚≠êÔ∏è
- 00:00 Introduction & Overview 
- 01:44 What is a Backend? 
- 02:01 Core Components: Languages, Databases, Runtimes, Frameworks 
- 04:36 Backend Architecture Flowchart 
- 05:44 How Frontend Connects to Backend (APIs) 
- 07:00 Prerequisites & Installing Node.js 
- 08:50 Project Folder Structure 
- 09:30 Project Initialization (Git & npm) 
- 12:56 Setting up MongoDB Atlas Database 
- 15:45 Environment Variables (.env) 
- 18:36 Constants & ES Modules Setup 
- 20:30 Creating the Express App (app.js) 
- 25:15 Connecting Database to Server (database.js) 
- 31:30 Server Entry Point (index.js) 
- 39:00 Setting up Nodemon & Running the Server 
- 44:00 Understanding Models & ER Diagrams 
- 46:26 Creating the User Model 
- 53:40 Understanding Routes 
- 55:00 Setting up User Routes 
- 56:23 Understanding Controllers 
- 1:57:04 Coding the Register Controller 
- 1:07:08 The Journey of a Request 
- 1:15:48 HTTP Methods & Status Codes Explained 
- 1:20:36 Introduction to Postman 
- 1:22:00 Testing the Register API 
- 1:25:53 Viewing Data in MongoDB Atlas 
- 1:27:14 Coding the Login Controller 
- 1:31:40 Hashing Passwords with Bcrypt 
- 1:36:40 Comparing Passwords for Login 
- 1:42:06 Testing the Login API 
- 1:44:04 Coding the Logout Controller 
- 1:47:40 Testing the Logout API 
- 1:49:14 Intro to CRUD APIs 
- 1:49:24 Creating the Post Model 
- 1:53:33 Create Post API (Controller & Route) 
- 2:59:52 Testing Create Post 
- 2:03:09 Read All Posts API 
- 2:05:54 Testing Get Posts 
- 2:08:30 Update Post API 
- 2:17:08 Testing Update Post 
- 2:19:36 Delete Post API 
- 2:23:47 Testing Delete Post 
- 2:25:13 Final Commit & Conclusion

‚ù§Ô∏è Support for this channel comes from our friends at Scrimba ‚Äì the coding platform that's reinvented interactive learning: https://scrimba.com/freecodecamp

üéâ Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
üëæ Drake Milly
üëæ Ulises Moralez
üëæ Goddard Tan
üëæ David MG
üëæ Matthew Springman
üëæ Claudio
üëæ Oscar R.
üëæ jedi-or-sith
üëæ Nattira Maneerat
üëæ Justin Hual

--

title: How to get back into coding after years away
description: If you've taken some time away from coding and want to get back into it, don't worry - totally doable. Tom talks about how he came back after a 7-year hiatus, found freeCodeCamp, and dove in.
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org
transcript:
What was the process of getting back
into programming like for you? Like like
where did you start? Because seven years
or so have passed. Like
>> I just grabbed my computer and said,
"How do I do this again?" Kind of opened
up some of my old programs, websites
that I had, I think, stored on one of my
old computers. And then I was like,
"Well, can I still do this or not?" And
so I started kind of creating new things
and obviously with the help of the
internet, it's not that difficult. Um,
yeah. And so I was kind of in the middle
of relearning and I did I found free
code camp through kind of a random
Google search or something. Opened it up
and it's pretty easy to get started. I
didn't have to even sign in or anything
and just started some challenges and I
had no intention of really sticking with
free code camp. I was learning things on
my own just fine. But yeah, I kind of
got hooked. It was pretty easy to earn
that first certification.

title: Harvard CS50 prof David J. Malan on why you should learn programming slowly [Podcast #197]
description:
Dr. David J. Malan teaches computer science at Harvard. Over the past decade, millions of people have taken his CS50 course both in person and online. He joins us to talk about:

1. Why he still recommends learning the C programming language in 2026
2. How he intentionally nerfs hist student's coding editors and LLMs to help them learn fundamentals faster
3. His vision for self-paced learning, and how it improves on traditional university education
4. Where the software engineering field is heading in light of recent AI tool improvements

Links from our discussion:

- Teaching Computer Science with Theatricality: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AMiNIjePZlo
- Teaching CS50 with AI: https://youtu.be/ggshaJcOc6Y
Dr. Malan's paper on Academic Honesty in CS50: https://cs.harvard.edu/malan/publications/Teaching_Academic_Honesty_in_CS50.pdf
- Dr. Malan's paper, Toward an Ungraded CS50: https://cs.harvard.edu/malan/publications/Toward_an_Ungraded_CS50.pdf
- My 2019 interview with Dr. Malan and Colton Ogden, one of his CS50 instructors: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/podcast-harvard-cs50s-david-malan-and-colton-ogden-on-computer-science/

Community news section:

1. Learn how cryptography works, and how developers use it to secure both data and communication. freeCodeCamp just published a course that will teach you Python functions for symmetric and asymmetric encryption. You'll learn about SHA-256, AES, RSA, and public / private keys as well. You'll even code your own command-line cryptography tool. (1 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/cryptography-for-beginners-full-python-course-sha-256-aes-rsa-passwords/

2. freeCodeCamp also published a course on building your own 3D games that run in a browser using Three.js and Blender. You'll learn how to model characters, design levels, detect collisions, and make the camera follow your playable character. You'll even deploy your game to the cloud so your friends can play it. (6 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/creative-web-development-with-threejs-and-blender/

3. Learn Event-Driven Architecture. freeCodeCamp published this advanced JavaScript handbook that will teach you about Event Loops, Task Queues, Call Stacks, Backpressure, Websockets, Pub/Sub, and more. Take your full stack development skills to the next level and be sure to share this with your developer friends. (full length handbook): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/event-based-architectures-in-javascript-a-handbook-for-devs/

4. freeCodeCamp also published our first ever guitar course. You'll learn beginner music theory concepts like chords and scales. You'll then map them to the guitar fretboard. You'll also learn guitar-specific techniques like barre chords. I learned guitar during the pandemic and am having an absolute blast with it. I hope you will, too. (1 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/guitar-theory-course-for-beginners-learn-fretboard-major-scale-and-triads

5. Check out the winner of this year's JS13k competition, Cat Strike. This cat stealth game was built using only 13 kilobytes of JavaScript, sound, assets, everything. You avenge your fallen human using wall climbing, rolling, meowing to distract, and of course, your claws. https://js13kgames.com/2025/games/clawstrike

Song of the Week: "Kiss Like Judas" by It Bites 1988: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LK4T8HnSdEI

but it feels to us like a reasonable
amount of time for students certainly to
have gotten some sleep and done some
reflection by then that if they come
forward to us um it will not be without
consequences still. will still still
typically zero the homework or the um
assignment in question. Um but we will
not escalate the matter further which is
to say we won't refer it further up to
the administrative board or the honor
council. So there is a bound on just how
bad that outcome might be. But more
important, more importantly,
educationally is it gives students an
opportunity to own that mistake and to
the extent they can make it right. And
it clarifies a priori exactly how bad or
scary the consequences will be because I
wouldn't fault a student not knowing
what's going to happen if they just come
forward to an arbitrary class that
doesn't have a stated policy. It just
feels even scarier um in situations like
that. So we aspired to try to turn this
into a so-called teachable moment by
defining the parameters by which
students could come forward.
>> Yeah. And uh I am very proud and I will
brag about this. I've never committed
academic dishonesty knowingly throughout
my entire academic career uh going
through K through 12 going to university
and grad school. Uh, but I can imagine
if you did commit some act of academic
dishonesty, whether that was just having
GPT write your paper for you or uh, you
know, cheating on an exam or something
like that, like there is an a chance
you're not going to get caught and
there's going to be no negative
consequence. Uh, so you have to do kind
of like an evaluation of okay, if I get
caught, it's really bad, but uh, if I
come forward, I'm definitely going to
have negative consequences. Just those
negative consequences are going to be
less severe. Uh so it's the kind of like
uh inevitability versus severity
trade-off that uh people have to think
about. But at the end of the day, it's
the right thing to just admit like, hey,
I screwed up and and this, you know, one
error does not need to, you know,
>> I don't have to feel guilty about this
for my entire life, right?
>> I I can just say what happened. And I
think it's so cool that you have that
clause. And I'm certainly uh we have
lots of people in the free code camp
community who come forward and they're
like you know what I did use an LLM to
write this code block for me and I
should have written it myself. I know
that I shouldn't have and uh then we're
like cool we've erased the challenge
just do it again. Uh and I I think like
actually adding some sort of regret
clause to pre-cooking because often we
have to strip people of their
certifications and stuff like that when
we detect these things. We do detect
these things. It happens a lot,
especially when you're outside of like
an academic setting. Like, nobody's
going to know that I just cheated my way
to getting this certification that I can
add to my LinkedIn. Uh, but I I think
it's a really cool clause. You also had
like something called a brink clause if
you can tell just I know that's no
longer something that you use, but just
in case people and I guess why you no
longer use that. Yeah, it was inspired
by a colleague Christopher Moretti at
Princeton who had a similar clause in
his syllabus. And the brink clause was
worded in such a way as to convey to
students that if you're bumping up a g a
deadline, which might be midnight for
instance in our case, and you're
genuinely concerned that you are on that
brink of making a poor decision,
grabbing a solution from the internet,
having a friend do it for you nowadays,
having AI do it for you. Um, you know
what? email us, explain your situation,
go to sleep, and we'll deal with it in
the morning, thereby giving you a bit of
extra time to work through it. Um, it
was a wonderful idea in spirit. The
intent was to be sort of a counterpart
to the regret clause to try to preempt
the poor decision by giving students an
out before they make that decision. In
practice, we felt that it was just
abused significantly in the sense that a
significant a number we felt was
significant of students were invoking
the bring clause right before the
deadline. And we did not, it was not our
impression from the the content and tone
of these emails that students were
indeed on the brink of making a a poor
decision with respect to academic
honesty, but rather that they hadn't
budgeted time correctly and they wanted
an out from the deadline, not from a
future bad act. And so it just wasn't
working as it was intended. And we felt
that um the regret clause educationally
was serving a better goal. And so we
eliminated the bring clause shortly
thereafter.
>> Awesome. And I really appreciate you
going into that uh experiment because a
lot of teachers might hear about those
sorts of things and that's anecdotal
evidence that people aren't necessarily
going to use it the way you intend. Uh
but it does sound like the regret clause
is working. Uh and you all intend to
continue to have that clause going
forward.
>> We do. Yep. And since we're talking
about academic dishonesty and academic
honesty, I did want to ask about
traditional A throughF letter grades and
whether you think those are potentially
deterring people from taking harder
classes like CS50 uh that would expand
their brain but potentially be a lot
harder than a lot of other electives
they might be able to take. What are
your thoughts on pass fail versus A
throughF grading skills and uh what have
what experimentation have you done in
that area?
>> Yeah, I think that risk is absolutely
possible in the students minds if they
takes a course that's too challenging
for them, too difficult, too much work
that they might indeed therefore hurt
their GPA and so they're not pursuing
areas of potential interest to them
academically for what I think many
teachers would argue is the wrong
reasons, the grading outcome. Um and
more generally with something like
computer science which has generally in
many students minds been a field to
beware in so far as they might think
themselves not computer people um we
have tried to attack that head-on in
CS50 and so at least on campus we have
long evangelized students taking the
course sat unsat satisfactory
unsatisfactory so to speak which is
essentially functionally equivalent to
what most people know as pass fail
whereby students simply have to meet a
certain threshold to be satisfactorily
graded in the course or unsatisfactorily
graded. It's it's binary, not uh
inappropriate for a computer science
course. The motivation though for us
within CS50 specifically is to been to
create an environment in which students
do not need to fear failure so to speak
even if failure is a B or a C or an
actual F. Um but rather they can feel
all the more empowered to explore uh
uncomfortable waters, less familiar
waters for them, particularly if they've
never studied something like computer
science or programming specifically. uh
within CS50 itself on campus about 30%
of students do now elect this sat onset
option it's not nearly as high as I
would like if I had my way the entire
course would be graded this way but
unfortunately there are other
departments on campus that require that
students take letter grades even in
their computer science course if they
want to get departmental credit in
another course so there's always been
some downward pressure there as a result
but online and at scale all of CS50's
courses via open courseware are
effectively graded un sat on in so far
as to receive a certificate students uh
need to receive a 70% or higher on all
of their work, which is consistent with
the line we draw on campus for SAT.
>> I'm a huge fan of Harvard and its work
in open educational resources. For
example, uh making a lot of massive open
online courses like CS50 available
through its partnership with MIT and
edex. uh and just in general I'm a fan
of CS50 and of you for taking so much of
your teaching and making it publicly
available to everyone to millions of
people around the world who want to
learn uh security who want to learn uh
CS fundamentals want to learn gamedev
from a Harvard professor uh I think it's
really really cool but I have to
acknowledge that even with uh everything
that Harvard's doing there is still
probably a gap between what is real and
what is potentially possible. Can you
talk about the gap there and like if you
could wave a magic wand how you would
change higher education in the US?
>> Wow, it's a tall order. Um so among my
recurring frustrations is the sort of
temporal structure of university
education and even high school and
earlier in the United States whereby in
the high school level at a place like
Harvard students are generally taking
four sometimes five classes at a time
and they're therefore multipplexing
among them over the course of a
semester. Like that's a lot of different
things to be spending time on and it's
to the exclusion of I think being able
to have a truly immersive academic
experience in the course. Um, by
contrast, for instance, a course I've
taught for years, uh, at Harvard Law
School is computer science for lawyers
or CS50 for lawyers. The structure for
which is wonderful because it fits into
what the law school calls their winter
session where is a three-week period
whereby the graduate students have an
opportunity to take one and only one
class immersively. And I dare say it is
among the most engaged, most committed
student audiences that I think we tend
to have over the course of a year
because they have so much less uh going
on during that same session. Uh this
allows us to have c for instance morning
lectures and then afternoon hands-on
labs and then to do it again the next
day and the next day and the next day.
And even though admittedly certainly
with something like programming I think
having some time for the material and
for yourself to breathe is important
certainly when it comes to certain
conceptual concepts certain hands-on
laboratories being able to do something
like that very immersively I think is
incredibly valuable. So for my part I
would much prefer to see the university
structure invol uh be that students take
one course at a time maybe two courses
just to give you a bit of variety and to
give you the opportunity to take a break
from one thing but three courses four
courses. I think back to high school,
seven different courses I was taking,
for instance, at any one time, one of
which might have been recess admittedly,
but that's a lot to sort of juggle all
at the same time and to distract oneself
with. So, I think structurally we can do
better. Um, and it's also, I think, the
traditional schedule that I think does
us a disservice. And I've been
increasingly feeling that students are
in a much better position taking a
course like CS50 online than they are by
physically coming to at least the
lectures in person in Sanders Theater.
And this is true for the undergraduates
who are not coming and are indeed
watching the lectures online and for our
many online students who are taking the
course via open courseware and platforms
like edex. If for the simplest of
reasons they can pause and fast forward
and rewind when something gets a little
bit confusing, they can go down the
rabbit hole of trying some code on their
computer or looking something up online.
And that is a lot harder, if not
impossible, to do synchronously when
you're in the lecture hall physically
with me for two hours and 45 minutes
because all of us zone out one or more
times during uh the day, let alone
during a class. And it's certainly not
to your educational benefit if that
completely derails you for the rest of
lecture just because you missed some
simple but important topic um just for
having zoned out. So I think leveraging
technology in a way that is a solution
to these temporal problems is just
significantly underappreciated by
traditional uh residential campuses um
at at all levels at least here in the
US.
>> Yeah. Yeah. So essentially making
education more convenient and also just
stripping out like the the time and
place uh to an extent so that people can
so so that they can fit people have to
petrist their lives around and
university not like non-traditional
learners if you're going to night school
if you're already working. Uh it can be
a huge burden to have to report to a
specific location at a specific time to
learn. And then there as you said the
fundamental restriction of you can't
pause of a live lecture. uh you can't
get up to go to the bathroom and not
miss something. You can't rewind to
rehear something like when I did this
your CS50 uh security course which you
taught which free co recently published.
Uh I just listened to it. Uh I I would
pull out my phone whenever there was
some sort of visual element that I
needed to see to fully understand. But a
lot of it I could just be uh you know
doing the dishes, taking my kids to
school and uh I could progress through
that over the course of maybe like seven
or eight different discrete se uh
sessions of learning. And granted, I
didn't do the labs or anything. I just
listened to the lectures, but I could
listen to them at double speed and I
could scrub back and relisten to a part
where I felt like I didn't fully
understand what was said. And these are
things that you just can't do in a
real-time uh lecture. So,
>> no. when we have a solution to this
problem and just so few schools are
embracing it for what it is good at I do
think.
>> Yeah. Yeah. Absolutely. So sounds like
that's one of the biggest value unlocks
for an institution is to potentially
follow in your footsteps in terms of
recording the lectures and making them
publicly available so people can consume
them kind of at their convenience. Uh
are there any other like fast quicks uh
fixes that you think could dramatically
help universities and university
students?
>> You know that too is a loaded question.
Quick fix. I don't know. But I will say
another thing that's top of mind is
outside of the US. We were recently in
the United Kingdom for instance for a
CS50 puzzle day and a CS50 hackathon.
And they in higher education have a
somewhat different system in which
students generally have to know what
they are going to study before they get
to university. And I have long felt well
how do they even know what they want to
study at that level if they haven't even
been exposed to all possible subjects in
K12 which is surely not generally
possible. And so there too, I think we
should be rethinking what students
trajectory is from the youngest of ages
to the oldest of ages while still in
school. So that everyone does have a
genuine opportunity to find their way in
terms of their passion, in terms of
their expertise, um, and to really set
them up for success in ways that I don't
think the structure in the US and beyond
necessarily does right now.
>> Yeah. And, uh, I'm not one of those
people that thinks, oh, Europe's got it
all figured out. like but taking the
general ed requirement and like kind of
pushing it down into high school or even
earlier uh so that people get exposed to
more subject domain areas before they
have to make the decision. And in the US
I guess the big constraint is once you
get to a university it becomes like
costly in terms of money like if you
have to do like a fifth year of school
because you weren't able to decide on a
major or you weren't able to get all the
classes lined up. uh that can provide a
lot of disincentive. Like I I talk to
people all the time that are almost done
with a major in like nursing and they're
like, "Well, I'm almost done and I'm
just going to get this nursing degree
and I I don't have time to switch to CS
and get all the requirements. It's going
to cost me a fortune. I'm going to go
even further into debt." So, there are
practical realities to that as well. Uh
at least the European system, like if
you don't get to change, you don't have
to worry about that kind of a situation
emerging because you're already locked
in. Uh but that's not optimal either,
right?
>> No. And here too, technology offers us a
partial solution here. Even if a school
is not so fortunate as to have all of
the teachers that it needs, all for all
the courses that it wants. Well, other
institutions can offer the same and we
can lean on each other and pull
collective resources so that a student
at one school can take a course somehow
technologically from a school elsewhere.
And I think we do too little of this
right now.
>> Yeah. Well, I have a ton of questions
for you coming from the developer
community. I tweeted out that I was
going to talk with you, and I've never
done this before, but I may do it more
frequently, but of course, everybody
knows who you are, and they had lots of
questions for you. So, we're just going
to do a rapid fire uh question and
answer round. Uh, and I want to start
with a question from my Vong. Uh, she
asks, "Which CS50 course is your
favorite to teach?" Oh, I think I have
to say I love them all equally, but in
so far as we teach CS50, aka CS50X, live
every fall and continue to evolve it the
most, that's probably my favorite, if
only because it's the course that I
myself took uh and the one that provides
a gateway to so many of our other
courses now.
>> Yeah. And a question from Kyle Furchin.
He asks, "How will CS50 adapt its
curriculum going forward?" I think in
light of AI is the context there.
>> Yeah, if if that's the implied question,
not fundamentally, honestly. I think AI,
at least for us, is a wonderful new
resource for students and for teachers
alike to help them master material
without having a subject matter expert
by their side in their family, in their
social circle. we can now provide in the
form of the duck for instance the
equivalent the near equivalent of a
virtual TA to every student out there
that I think is gamechanging and I think
we'll continue to invest and to focus on
how that duck or its future form can
continue to support students. I don't
think that curricularly I don't think
that structurally we intend to change
the courses all that much because I'd
like to think that we've long focused
truly on the fundamentals that we feel
students should master with or without
AI and in so far as most of CS50's
courses are introductory in nature that
foundation is rather invariant across
the courses
>> and I'll just opine here that's
precisely how I view free code camp's
core curriculum uh we're not
fundamentally changing anything because
we're focusing on fundamentals And
fundamentals haven't fundamentally
changed. It's just that tools for
understanding and reasoning about those
fundamentals. Uh we have additional
arrows in the quiver, right? Uh
additional tools in the toolbox.
>> Uh what what's your workflow for
producing these courses? I don't know if
you can go through like just the general
production because they are very
polished.
>> Well, thank you. There's a whole team
off camera behind me and behind the
scenes that makes that all possible. Uh,
back in the day when I first started
teaching CS50 in 2007, I think we were a
single camera shot. And if you wanted to
see what was going on on the slides over
my head, we would just take the Sony
camcorder and just point it up here for
a few seconds and then back down here
wreaking havoc with the iris and the
lighting settings in in fact. But, uh,
it was still usable and we made even
that content available online early on.
Nowadays, I work with a whole team of
talented artists who operate as many as
five cameras at once. Uh, some of them
are now robotically controlled just to
give us beautiful shots back and forth
on the stage. One of which is always
locked off on our green screen which we
tuck off into the corner of the stage so
that you can actually see the code
composited behind me uh as large as
possible. Um, we then after capturing
the live assets which we do live stream
in raw form uh we then go back to the
drawing board and edit everything. So we
have an internal process where one or
more of the team members will take
charge of editing all of the footage
from those five cameras together even
though we do have a live cut with which
we might begin uh go we then have two QA
processes whereby a member of the staff
watches and reviews the content again
and again both for technical accuracy
and uh and academic accuracy. On
occasion, uh, we'll go back into Sanders
before, for instance, the next class and
shoot a bunch of audio pickups if I
misspoke or said something wrong or or,
uh, incomprehensible. Uh, or sometimes
video segments if either I did something
completely wrong or we ran out of time
or I don't like how something came out,
we might do those edits. Um, but it's a
very time consuming process and we try
to optimize ultimately for what the
student experience is, especially since
these courses in in our practice at
least tend to have a long shelf life of
at least a year if not two or three or
four or more years nowadays. So, we'd
like to get them just right.
>> Yeah. And shout out uh to the person who
asked that question by the way, Rulo
Aruda. The next question comes from Aul
uh who asked what advice do you have for
picking strong projects to build?
>> Oh,
I have myself chosen projects that are
just solutions to problems that I myself
have in my life and nowadays they're
almost always connected to CS50 or
teaching more broadly in some way. In
fact, I really enjoy working on some of
CSS's web-based tools and command line
tools because I know they have an
audience and there are tools I think
should exist. And so if I or we don't
make them, they just won't. And so
that's sort of intrinsically motivating
for me. Very early on when I was sort of
finding my way and learning computer
science and programming specifically, I
set out even then to solve a problem of
interest to me or at least people in my
world. So when I was a sophomore or
junior at Harvard, after having taken
CS50 and one other class in which I
learned a bit of C++, I set out to
create what was called Shuttle Boy,
which was a uh Unixbased program written
in C or C++ that simply let students
look up the next time and location that
a shuttle bus would arrive. Back in the
day, we only had printed uh sheets of
paper. Uh there was no GPS, there were
no smartphones. Uh and so the best we
could do is evolve it to something
digital. So if you, you know, went over
to the computer kiosk in the nearby
building, you could check the schedule
and then run outside to actually catch
the shuttle bus over time that evolved
into an instant messaging bot. Over
time, Harvard took it sort of back over
and had uh GPS added to the mix. But for
me, that was so wonderfully exciting as
an undergraduate having hundreds, maybe
even at the peak thousands of my
classmates actually using a piece of
software I wrote. So finding something
that you care about and better still
other people care about I think is the
best way to really uh immerse yourself
and learn more about code.
>> Awesome. So finding something you care
about that other people care about and
building something that people are going
to use and of course once you have
people using it you have a feedback loop
and it becomes very uh clear what kind
of improvements you need to make so you
can just continue to uh maintain that
project. Excellent advice. And then uh
we have a question from Nevin who asks,
"What tips do you have to self-taught
developers to make the process for
preparing for work as a developer as
short as possible?"
>> I'm not sure that should be the goal to
make it as short as possible. I
completely understand the motivation and
the opportunity cost of sort of spending
time educating yourself or preparing in
this case for a job. But I think the
reality is a lot of mastery just comes
with time and with practice. And I think
it's probably the wrong mindset, perhaps
an unhealthy mindset to go into
something trying to rush it or at least
to minimize that amount of time. I think
what you the probably a better way to
frame it is how do I maximize the value
of my time? So whatever unit of time I'm
actually putting into preparation or
learning something that I'm getting the
most out of it. And through the lens of
CS50 for instance, this is just one of
the reasons why CS50 itself is fairly
intensive and has such a large syllabus.
This amalgam of what other places tend
to call CS1 and CS2 because at least on
campus in a traditional environment,
we've only ever had our students with us
for some 12 weeks. So 3 months and so if
that's the variable that's constrained,
we want to optimize for what we can
achieve in those 12 weeks. So I think
that's probably the better way to frame
things as opposed to how you minimize uh
the denominator for instance.
>> Awesome. And one question I have for
you, how do you remember the names of
all your students? Uh I frequently hear
when you're answering questions from the
audience offscreen in your courses,
you'll address the student by name. And
you are sitting in the region theater
which is huge. You've got tons of seats.
Uh and you often record in other
theaters as well, right? Um and so like
imagine a class of potentially hundreds
of learners there. Like how do you keep
track of all those names? Do you have
any advice to people for remembering
people's names?
>> I admittedly don't. I don't remember the
hundreds of names that are there. But I
certainly over the course of a semester
on campus get to know uh some of the
students typically those who are the
most participatory in class. We also
have a tradition of bringing students to
lunch at a nearby restaurant most
Fridays during the term. The the
motivation for which is to help a big
class feel small and to actually meet
students wearing literally not just uh
hello my name is name tags but hello
world my name is name tags and that
helps ingrain some of them in me. I get
to know our teaching fellows quite well
on campus over time. Certainly those who
TA for us again and again. Um and then
when students come up onto stage uh if
I've not met them before that's the
moment to meet them, get to know a
little something about them. Uh at which
point they then tend to stick in mind
thereafter as well.
>> Final question. You have said get
comfortable being uncomfortable.
Can you elaborate on this for people who
are about to take the plunge and learn
something as potentially daunting as
computer science and programming?
Yeah, at least in the context of
computer science and programming, it's
just such a vast space already and it's
only getting larger and larger with more
and more advancements and technologies
and products out there that I don't
think you'll ever feel comfortable in it
because there's always going to be
something you don't yet know because it
only came out like the day before. And
this is true certainly for teaching.
Anytime I take on a new course, it's
incredibly uncomfortable because I don't
know what the students are going to ask
me and I don't want to look like an
idiot and not being able to answer their
question correctly. And even in an
interview like this, sort of being on
edge, not knowing quite where the
conversation is going to go. But I think
there's therefore value in just
embracing the fact, okay, I'm about to
do something, whether it's learning
something, teaching something,
interviewing with someone, that I will
be uncomfortable. also to just kind of
own that and to get comfortable being in
that space and not letting the
proverbial butterflies for instance get
the best of you. I mean, to this day, 19
years into teaching CS50, I'm still
nervous going into the very first class.
And admittedly, I'm not as nervous as I
originally was. The very first or second
year I taught CS50, I still remember
iPods did exist at the time already, and
I was trying to turn on some music just
to play as walk-in music as students
entered the class. and I couldn't
operate the iPod that day because my
hands were so sweaty the screen would
not respond. So for me that's sort of
the pinnacle of like nervousness and I
have throttled that back enough so that
I'm still nervous. I'm still
uncomfortable but I'm much more
comfortable now because I know it's not
going to be the end of the world. I know
that 5 seconds into class beginning I'm
going to finally feel at ease. Those
butterflies are going to dissipate. And
so through practice and through time,
I've just gotten myself comfortable
being uncomfortable just as we encourage
our own students when stepping foot in
the classroom for the first time
themselves.
>> Well, David, thank you for, you know,
sharing that vulnerability. Uh just the
discomfort doesn't completely go away,
but it does dissipate a little bit and
then uh you can feel confident that once
you get started, you're going to lock in
and you're going to be able to perform.
And I think that's advice uh listeners
can take to heart. I really appreciate
everything you're doing through CS50. I
appreciate the fact that you're making
so many of these courses like C uh
Creative Commons licensed and just
making them free and open for everyone.
I encourage everybody tuning in to watch
some of the CS50 lectures and
potentially even participate and do all
the assignments that are available and
things like that. Uh and I really
appreciate you making time out of your
busy day to answer my many questions and
these questions from the community.
Thanks again for everything you're
doing. Thank you for having me.

title: Don't settle for boring text underlines...make them more fun!
description: Don't settle for boring text underlines...make them more fun! Ania shows you how to do it using CSS here.
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org
transcript:
Boring straight underlines. Try text
decoration style. Wavy, dotted, or
dashed.

title: Discrete Mathematics Course for Beginners
description:
Learn discrete mathematics in this beginner's course. Discrete mathematics plays a key role in IT solutions, used in machine learning, accelerating queries in search engines and databases, in algorithms such as finding the shortest paths (graph theory), encryption, compression, and many other modern systems/solutions.

This field is constantly evolving along with the development of its key application: computer science. This course is an introduction to this group of mathematical sciences, and we will focus on the most important issues on which other branches of discrete mathematics are based: combinatorics, number theory, prime numbers, and several selected topics: pigeonhole principle, stars and bars principle, Stirling's number, and the Chinese remainder theorem. At the end of the course, there are tips and encouragement for further exploration of this field.

Karol Kurek teaches this course. He is a former math teacher and senior Python developer.

title: If you're struggling, don't isolate yourself - find someone you can talk to.
description: If you're struggling, don't isolate yourself. Find people you can talk to and take care of your physical and mental health. Ihechikara talks with Quincy about his past struggles with isolation and how he overcame them on the freeCodeCamp podcast.
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org
transcript:
The first advice is do not isolate
yourself. This was the first mistake I
made when I had these issues in the
past. I had one major problem. It felt
as if I was having like unfortunate
events happen and then when I finally
got placed on academic progression, I
felt like that was like the the boiling
point came crashing. So I sort of like
isolated myself at that point. Lost
interest in a ton of things. But the
advice I would give is try and talk to
people. Do not neglect your health. This
is one other thing that I failed at.
After I got the job, when the aspect of
like family finances started getting way
easier, I realized that I had done a lot
of damage to my health, specifically my
physical and mental health. I had issues
with sleeping. Find people that you can
talk to, somebody you trust.

title: n8n Course for Beginners ‚Äì Build Complex Workflows & Master AI Integration
description:
Learn n8n in this full course for beginners from @GavinLon. n8n is an open-source workflow automation platform that lets you connect different apps, APIs, and services to easily automate tasks without needing to implement extensive code. You'll learn the practical steps of setting up n8n and then dive into four comprehensive workflow examples, including an AI-powered chatbot and an emergency WhatsApp notification system.

Support Files on GitHub: https://github.com/GavinLonDigital/n8n_FCC_Workflows_Support_Docs

OAuth2 Explainer Video: https://youtu.be/-ENPtwwW-tQ

Self-host your n8n workflows with Hostinger:  https://hostinger.com/getstartedn8n and use code GETSTARTED to claim your discount.

üèóÔ∏è Hostinger provided a grant to make this course possible.

‚≠êÔ∏è Contents ‚≠êÔ∏è
- 0:00:00 Introduction
- 0:10:35 Discussing Internet Standards, REST and OAuth2
- 0:14:49 Getting Started - Setup n8n on Hostinger (self-hosted)
- 0:18:36 Create First Workflow Example (AI - Chatbot)
- 0:21:23 Add an AIAgent Node to Workflow
- 0:25:00 Add OpenAI Chat Model sub node to AiAgent Node
- 0:26:49 Add Credentials to OpenAI Chat Model sub node
- 0:33:40 Add a System Prompt to AIAgent Node
- 0:41:00 Add Memory Sub Node to AiAgent (to Add Context)
- 0:43:35 Test ChatBot WorkFlow
- 0:45:27 Logging on to Hostinger and n8n
- 0:46:42 Create Workflow Example 2 (WhatsApp Panic App Registration)
- 0:47:10 Create Google Spreadsheet
- 0:49:47 Add and Setup OnSubmission Form Trigger Node 
- 0:58:03 Add and Setup Google Sheets Node
- 0:58:49 Setup Credentials for Google Sheets Node (using OAuth2)
- 1:15:22 Create Workflow Example 3 (WhatsApp Panic Notifications)
- 1:17:27 Add WhatsApp Trigger Node and Setup Credentials
- 1:29:27 Setup other Workflow Nodes (WhatsApp Panic Notifications)
- 1:45:32 Test WhatsApp Panic App Notifications Workflow
- 1:47:43 Create Workflow Example 4 (CV Approval / Interview Scheduler)
- 1:52:32 Setup Google Drive Node and Configure Credentials
- 2:01:33 Setup Loop Node
- 2:16:59 Setup Human in the Loop Node
- 2:31:03 Setup AIAgent Node for Scheduling Interview on Google Calendar
- 2:54:21 Test CV Approval / Interview Scheduler Workflow - Human in the Loop
- 3:04:06 Abstract Sub-WorkFlow to Create Separation of Concerns
- 3:15:39 Extra Information
- 3:15:59 Use WhatsApp to Converse with ChatBot in Example 1
- 3:19:57 Use A WebHook Trigger Node to Trigger your Workflow
- 3:22:32 Use the HttpRequest node to make Requests to External Web Apis From Workflow
- 3:24:24 Integrate JavaScript Code into Workflow using Code Node
- 3:28:58 Outro
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org

title: Guess how many bugs NASA's space shuttle software had?

title: This hackathon team built a tool to help blind and visually impaired people learn Braille

transcript:
Did you know that only a small
percentage of the blind population can
actually read Braille?
>> We didn't, but we wanted to do something
about it. So, at NW Hacks, we built
Braille Learn, which is a system that
allows the visually impaired to learn
Braille without needing the help of a
sighted person. We have the Braille box
and our learning app working together
for an interactive experience.
>> In display mode, you can say or type in

spell out each character. Quincy is
being displayed.
>> And by feeling the raised dots, the
learner can begin to recognize familiar
words and characters in Braille. Our app
is also entirely keyboard and screen
reader friendly, making it accessible to
everyone. Under the hood, we have six uh
servo motors powered by our Arduino.
They push up uh some aluminum pins that
serve as the rail dots.

title: Learn Vue.js ‚Äì Tutorial for Beginners
description:
Learn Vue as you build real projects, dive into its core features, and create dynamic, reusable, and reactive apps with ease.

‚úèÔ∏è Study this course interactively on Scrimba: 
https://scrimba.com/learn-vue-c0jrrpaasr?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=video&utm_campaign=fcc-learn-vue 

Code is available on the Scrimba course page for each lesson.

Vue.js is a progressive JavaScript framework for building user interfaces and single-page applications. Loved for its simplicity, flexibility, and performance, it allows developers to start small and scale up to complex applications with ease. Whether you‚Äôre creating quick prototypes or production-ready projects, Vue‚Äôs approachable syntax and strong community make it an excellent tool to have in your toolkit.

Scrimba on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/c/Scrimba

0:03:49 Vue.js - What and Why?
0:06:28 Your First Vue App

title: The HTML blink tag was SO annoying it got binned. The more you know...
description: The HTML blink tag was SO annoying it got binned. The more you know...
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org
transcript:
Did you know that HTML blink tag is a
non-standard HTML element that was
supported by some web browsers in the
past? It was used to make tags blink on
and off, creating a flashing effect on
the web page. Now you know.

title: Z-index not working right? Here's how to fix your layering nightmares
description: Z-index not working? Try isolation: isolate on the parent element. This creates a new stacking context and fixes those layering nightmares so you can stack with confidence.
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org
transcript:
Z index not working. Try isolation.
Isolate on the parent element.

title: Perfectionism holds new developers back with Abbey Perini [Podcast #196]
description:
Abbey Perini taught herself programming at age 27 while working as an admin at an engineering recruitment agency. She has worked extensively with large legacy codebases and taught best practices to developers internationally.

We talk about:
- How to hit the ground running with a large legacy codebase
- How to get employers to remember you and actually respond to you
- How she adapted to her ADHD diagnosis and stays focused and ships code
- How knitting and cosplay give her perspective as a dev

Links we discuss:
- Abbey's blog: https://abbeyperini.com/
- Robby Russell (OhMyZSH maintainer) interview: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/podcast-oh-my-zsh-creator-and-ceo-robby-russell/
- Leon (100Devs founder) interview: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/playing-the-developer-job-search-game-to-win-in-2025-with-danny-thompson-and-leon-noel-podcast-188/
- AskJan to help you figure out if you need accomodation at work and your options: https://askjan.org/
- Little Old Lady Memory: https://www.amusingplanet.com/2020/02/that-time-when-computer-memory-was.html

Links from the community news section:

1. freeCodeCamp just published a new course taught by legendary Harvard computer science professor Dr. David J. Malan. This comprehensive cybersecurity for beginners course will teach you how to secure accounts, databases, and entire software systems. Dr. Malan also shares tons of practical tips for securing your privacy in an increasingly adversarial world. (8 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/learn-cybersecurity-from-harvard-university/

2. freeCodeCamp also published a guide to passing the Certified Kubernetes Administrator Exam. Beau Carnes teaches this course, which will walk you through key DevOps concepts. You'll start by setting up your K8s practice environment. Then you'll bootstrap a multi-node cluster and your control plane. You'll learn about Helm, High Availability Autoscaling, CoreDNS, and more. (2 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/prepare-for-the-kubernetes-administrator-certification-and-pass/

3. Learn how to build high-performance mobile apps using Google's open-source Flutter framework. freeCodeCamp uses Flutter for our Android and iPhone apps, and it's way easier than maintaining two separate app codebases. This Flutter handbook will teach you how to efficiently lay out your apps with minimum widget rebuilds. You'll learn state management techniques, asynchronous patterns, and image caching best practices. You'll also learn how to use Isolates and lazy loading to make your apps really snappy. (full length handbook): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/how-to-build-scalable-and-performant-flutter-applications-a-handbook-for-devs/

4. Learn Serverless Architecture using C# .NET and Azure cloud. This jam-packed course will teach you common microservice patterns, Onion Architecture, IoT functions, and more. (5 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/serverless-and-microservices-with-c-and-azure/

5. If you want to listen to lofi music in the background while you work with lower data consumption (64kbps or 128kbps) than YouTube and no ads, freeCodeCamp has got your covered: https://coderadio.freecodecamp.org

The song of the week is Marvin Gaye's "A Funky Space Reincarnation" released on New Year's Day 1978. Tons of funky solos, a laid back drum groove, and Marvin doing some James Brown-style vocal punctuations: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zk8-EXnFSjw

Buy a freeCodeCamp shirt: https://shop.freecodecamp.org

The freeCodeCamp community is working hard on so many improvements to our core curriculum. You should support our charity's mission, and by extension the entire open source ecosystem that relies on our learning resources: https://www.freecodecamp.org/donate

Contents
- 0:00:00 Intro: FreeCodeCamp News & Guest Abbey Perini
- 0:03:00 Legacy Codebases: Common Mistakes & Best Practices
- 0:10:07 The Commenting Debate: When to Use Them
- 0:15:37 Non-Traditional Path to Coding: Education & Career
- 0:22:24 Bootcamp Experience vs. Self-Learning/Free Resources
- 0:26:01 Insider Advice on Recruiters and the Job Search
- 0:33:04 ADHD Diagnosis: Impact on Life and Work
- 0:39:50 The Maker Background: Knitting, Cosplay, and Coding Overlaps
- 0:48:47 Hacking Motivation: Finding Joy in the Technical Tasks
- 0:51:50 Outro & Final Thoughts

title: How to focus your efforts in the right directions when job hunting
description: When you're job hunting, it's easy to feel exhausted and low energy. But if you can figure out how to tweak a couple things, you'll be able to stand out and move forward. Leon and Danny discuss this with Quincy on the freeCodeCamp podcast.
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org
transcript:
So, I think a lot of times people were
sold a vision on college. They were sold
a vision on a boot camp. They were sold
a vision on something that made it seem
like the tail end was going to be a
little bit easier than it actually is.
And when you're in the thick of it, when
now your resources are depleted, your
energy is lower, and now you have to do
this other part of the job process that
you didn't know about. I get it. Like, I
get why that is overwhelming. It's hard.
But the folks that can figure out how to
tweak things, the folks that are able to
put more shots on net, they continue and
will always continue to keep getting
jobs.
>> You have more control over the job
search than you realize, but spinning in
a circle waste a lot of energy and you
feel like you're really doing something
meaningful. But really audit your
actions. Like really audit them. Are
exhausted every single day. It's a good
sign that you've put in effort, but have
you placed it in the right areas?

title: Cryptography for Beginners - Full Python Course (SHA-256, AES, RSA, Passwords)
description:
Learn about cryptography in this beginner's course. You'll learn essential techniques like hashing (SHA-256) for verifying file integrity, symmetric encryption (AES), and asymmetric encryption (RSA) using public and private keys.  The practical focus of the tutorial involves building a fully functional command-line cryptography tool in Python.  Upon completion, you'll have a complete practical toolkit and the skills to safeguard data, secure passwords, and deter tampering.

This course was developed by Thanishkka. She is part of Hack Club. Hack Club is a global non-profit organization that creates a community for high school students interested in coding and making things with technology.

Hack Club is free and any teenager can join. Check out their site to get stickers and learn more: https://hackclub.com/

‚≠êÔ∏è Contents ‚≠êÔ∏è
- 00:00 Introduction: What is Cryptography?
- 00:36 About Hack Club and the Course Creator
- 01:09 Cryptography Basics & Cybershe Demo
- 02:26 Three Main Areas: Hashing, Symmetric, and Asymmetric Encryption
- 03:09 Deep Dive into Hashing (SHA 256) and File Integrity
- 04:37 Symmetric Encryption with AES (Key, IV, and Modes)
- 07:20 Asymmetric Encryption with RSA (Public and Private Keys)
- 09:37 Setup: Python and VS Code Installation
- 10:40 Creating and Activating a Virtual Environment
- 12:15 Installing Required Python Libraries (cryptography, zxcvbn, bcrypt)
- 13:46 Coding the File Hashing Function (hash.py)
- 18:36 Coding the File Integrity Verification Function
- 22:05 Coding AES Symmetric Encryption/Decryption (encryption.py)
- 26:26 Coding RSA Asymmetric Encryption/Decryption
- 30:03 Coding the Password Strength Checker (password.py)
- 35:28 Coding Password Hashing and Verification (using bcrypt)
- 39:27 Building the Command Line UI (main.py)
- 47:26 Final Toolkit Demo and Testing
- 49:15 Conclusion and Next Steps

üëæ Oscar R.

title: Why you should support your favorite open source projects
description: Open source projects often struggle to get sponsorships and support from the community. Evan You, creator of Vue and Vite, explains how he's trying to address this problem on the freeCodeCamp podcast.
channel_description: Learn math, programming, and computer science for free. A 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charity. We also run a free learning interactive platform at freecodecamp.org

title: Creative Web Development with Three.js and Blender ‚Äì 3D Portfolio for Beginners
description:
Learn Creative Web Development with Three.js and Blender! This beginner-friendly course will teach you to create an immersive 3D portfolio. You'll begin by diving into Blender to learn the fundamentals of 3D modeling. With your 3D assets complete, you will learn Three.js to bring your 3d models to the web.

Code, Credits, Fixes, Updates & Blender File: https://github.com/andrewwoan/bellas-park

Website: https://www.bellas-park.com/

Course created by @andrewwoan 

https://ko-fi.com/andrewwoan

‚ù§Ô∏è Support for this channel comes from our friends at Scrimba ‚Äì the coding platform that's reinvented interactive learning: https://scrimba.com/freecodecamp

Chapters:
- 0:00:00 Introduction & project demo
- 0:01:58 Prerequisites
- 0:02:16 What is creative web development?
- 0:06:37 Learning first steps with Blender
- 0:14:05 (optional) Learning exercise - Think like a 3D artist
- 0:15:44 Modeling tree (bad and good ways)
- 0:42:16 Modeling character
- 1:16:33 Starting materials
- 1:29:37 (optional) Other things you can model
- 1:37:37 Modeling ground & level
- 1:41:34 Adding image textures for projects
- 1:51:35 A look at modeling some paths
- 1:53:57 A look at different cameras
- 1:59:03 How I modeled my scene
- 2:09:04 Adding text & signs
- 2:18:52 Preparing to export: checking normals, deleting faces, etc.
- 2:27:47 Export model
- 2:30:43 Viewing exported model with three.js editor
- 2:33:43 Starting coding with VS code
- 2:37:47 Getting started with three.js
- 3:07:07 (optional) Learning exercise - Make your camera move away
- 3:09:35 Quality of life adjustments
- 3:19:50 Loading & preparing our model
- 3:26:45 Updating camera & lighting
- 3:48:33 (optional) Learning exercise - Change a material color with three.js
- 3:51:48 Object interactions with raycaster
- 4:18:22 Character movement with GSAP
- 4:42:46 Collision detection implementation & custom movement
- 4:59:30 How to understand and approach difficult code from three.js examples
- 5:03:45 Collision detection implementation & custom movement
- 5:29:31 A look back on analyzing difficult code
- 5:31:02 Code & scene cleanup
- 5:32:02 Make camera follow player
- 5:35:27 (optional) Learning exercises: loading screen, mobile movement, theme switcher
- 5:37:41 Deployment with GitHub and Vercel
- 5:38:46 Final words and thoughts

title: How to Compete Against the Global Dev Talent Pool with Patrick Hartley [Podcast #195]
description:
Patrick Hartley is a self-taught developer with nearly a decade of software engineering experience. When he was 21 he had to dropped out of college to provide for his family. He taught himself programming while working at a thrift store.

After building his own apps and freelancing, he became the founding engineer at startup that got acquired, and has since worked as a dev at other tech companies. A few months ago he turned down an opportunity at Amazon so he could continue to work remotely from his home in Oklahoma City.

He shares tips for:
- Teaching yourself programming while raising kids
- How to build foundational skills with JavaScript and Python
- Getting a remote job when you have to compete with the global developer talent pool
- Surviving as an introvert in a networking-heavy and meeting-filled profession

Patrick Hartley on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/patrick-hartley-jr/

Links from the Community News intro: 

1. freeCodeCamp just published a massive course that will teach you almost every major data structure and algorithm that may come up in a developer job interview. You'll learn about Time Complexity, Space Complexity, and Big O Notation. Then you'll learn concepts like Trees, Graphs, Dynamic Programming, Backtracking, and more. (49 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/master-technical-interviews-by-learning-data-structures-and-algorithms/

2. freeCodeCamp also published a handbook that will teach you React for beginners. React is a powerful front end development library that tons of companies use to make their websites more interactive. If you already know some basic HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, this handbook is for you. You'll learn about JSX, components, event handlers, hooks, and more. (full length handbook): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/react-handbook-for-beginners-learn-jsx-hooks-rendering/

3. This SwiftUI for Beginners course will give you the tools you need to build your first iPhone app. You can code along at home and build your own movie browsing app with powerful search features and the ability to stream movie trailers. You'll learn about navigation, API networking requests, SwiftData, and more. (4 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/learn-swiftui-and-create-an-ios-app-from-scratch/

4. freeCodeCamp published an advanced Python tutorial on Machine Learning Lineage. This is important to establish the safety of mission critical AI systems. You'll learn about ETL Pipelines, Data Drift Checks, Model Tuning, and Model Risk Assessment. (20 minute read): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/how-to-build-end-to-end-machine-learning-lineage/

5. This relaxing 3D browser game where you deliver messages around town. You can customize your appearance and watch other messagers spawn into the game and deliver their packages, too. A chill way to spend 15 minutes. https://messenger.abeto.co/

6. Song of the week: A full live set from Anime-inspired French House producer Moe Shop. He takes his new album and glitches the ever living heck out of. If you like dance music I think you're going to love this. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l7DxUZmqvQA

Contents
0:00 Introduction and Free Code Camp Community Updates
3:54 The Self-Taught Developer's Journey: Dropping Out to Provide for Family
6:09 Competing for Remote Jobs and Turning Down Big Tech (Amazon)
14:03 The Value of Mentorship, Networking, and Practical Projects
22:55 Evolving Job Market: Soft Skills vs. Technical Proficiency in Specific Stacks
30:21 Choosing the Right Tech Stack: Open Source (JS/Python) vs. Enterprise (.NET)
36:27 Succeeding in a New Developer Job and Mastering the Art of Asking Questions
40:48 Managing Meetings and Finding Work-Life Balance as an Introverted Team Lead
50:35 Conclusion and Final Thoughts

get from playing chess that can transfer
into software development. And I'd say
the first one should be creativity.

have to be very creative when you play
chess. There are an infinite number of
positions that can appear in a chess
board. It's just 64 squares, but there
are so many ways that you can play

there are so many things you can do with

title: Harvard CS50‚Äôs Intro to Cybersecurity ‚Äì Full University Course
description:
This full-length course is an introduction to cybersecurity for technical and non-technical audiences alike. You'll learn how to secure your accounts, data, systems, and software against today‚Äôs threats and how to recognize and evaluate tomorrow‚Äôs as well, both at home and at work. Learn how to preserve your own privacy. Learn to view cybersecurity not in absolute terms but relative, a function of risks and rewards (for an adversary) and costs and benefits (for you). Learn to recognize cybersecurity as a trade-off with usability itself. 

This course presents both high-level and low-level examples of threats, providing students with all they need know technically to understand both. Assignments inspired by real-world events.

why does this break? Well, let and const
are hoisted but not initialized until
the line where they're declared. They
exist in the temporal dead zone. So this
is an error not undefined.

title: Kubernetes Course ‚Äì Certified Kubernetes Administrator Exam Preparation
description:
Lean Kubernetes and prepare to pass the Certified Kubernetes Administrator (CKA) examination. This course is designed to provide a deep, practical understanding of Kubernetes administration, from foundational concepts to advanced troubleshooting. 

üíª All commands and code from the course (link will work soon): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/prepare-for-the-kubernetes-administrator-certification-and-pass

Course developed by @beau 

üèóÔ∏è The Linux Foundation provided a grant to make this course possible. 

‚≠êÔ∏è Course Contents ‚≠êÔ∏è
‚å®Ô∏è 0:00:00 Introduction

‚å®Ô∏è 0:04:17 Kubernetes Fundamentals and Lab
- Understanding the Kubernetes Architecture
- Core Kubernetes Objects
- Setting Up Your CKA Practice Environment

‚å®Ô∏è 0:20:03 Cluster Architecture, Installation & Configuration
- Bootstrapping a Multi-Node Cluster with kubeadm
- Managing the Cluster Lifecycle
- Implementing a Highly-Available (HA) Control Plane
- Managing Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
- Application Management with Helm and Kustomize
- Extending Kubernetes

‚å®Ô∏è 0:53:17 Workloads & Scheduling
- Mastering Deployments
- Configuring Applications with ConfigMaps and Secrets
- Implementing Workload Autoscaling
- Advanced Pod and Container Configuration
- Advanced Scheduling

‚å®Ô∏è 1:23:58 Services & Networking
- Pod-to-Pod Connectivity
- Kubernetes Services
- Ingress and the Gateway API
- Network Policies
- CoreDNS

‚å®Ô∏è 1:41:39 Storage
- Volumes, PersistentVolumes (PV), and PersistentVolumeClaims (PVC)
- Volume Configuration
- StorageClasses and Dynamic Provisioning

‚å®Ô∏è 1:53:25 Troubleshooting
- The Troubleshooting Methodology
- Troubleshooting Applications and Pods
- Troubleshooting Cluster and Nodes
- Troubleshooting Cluster Components
- Troubleshooting Services and Networking
- Monitoring Cluster and Application Resource Usage

‚å®Ô∏è 2:02:50 Conclusion
